segments.en: And today we're going to be looking at English slang and informal words used in the 1980s.
segments.cn: 今天我们将讨论1980年代的英语俚语和非正式用语。

segments.en: So this is the next part of our decades dialogues.
segments.cn: 这是我们十年对话的下一部分。

segments.en: So the 1980s maybe for many of our listeners is a little bit more familiar.
segments.cn: 对于许多听众来说，1980年代可能更为熟悉。

segments.en: And there are a lot of phrases and a lot of words that were born in this decade and we still use them today.
segments.cn: 这个年代诞生了很多短语和单词，我们至今仍在使用。

segments.en: So we're going to learn those words and phrases in this dialogue.
segments.cn: 所以我们将在这个对话中学习这些单词和短语。

segments.en: But before we start, we need to preview a couple of words.
segments.cn: 但在开始之前，我们需要预览几个单词。

segments.en: Let's go now to vocabulary preview.
segments.cn: 现在让我们进行词汇预览。

segments.en: So one of the words that we're going to hear in our dialogue is ride.
segments.cn: 我们在对话中将听到的一个单词是ride。

segments.en: Normally we know this word as a verb, right?
segments.cn: 通常我们知道这个词是动词，对吧？

segments.en: In this context, it's an informal way of referring to your car.
segments.cn: 在这个语境中，它是指你的车的非正式说法。

segments.en: So a ride is a car.
Yeah, so I just bought a new ride.
segments.cn: 是的，我刚买了一辆新车。

segments.en: All right, well maybe you'll take me for a ride in your new ride.
segments.cn: 好吧，也许你会带我去兜风。

segments.en: And we're also going to be looking at this word loaded.
So if you are loaded, you're really rich.
segments.cn: 如果你很有钱，那你就是loaded。

segments.en: You have a lot of money.
Those are our two words for vocabulary preview.
segments.cn: 这就是我们词汇预览的两个单词。

segments.en: And well, let's listen to our 1980s dialogue and see what happens.
segments.cn: 好吧，让我们听听1980年代的对话，看看会发生什么。

segments.en: I just need to fix it up a bit.
segments.cn: 我只需要稍微修理一下。

segments.en: In a couple of months, this baby is going to be wicked.
segments.cn: 几个月后，这辆车会很酷。

segments.en: Too bad the driver's a major dweeb.
Anyone can have a car like that if their daddy's loaded like his.
segments.cn: 如果他的爸爸有钱，任何人都可以有这样的车。

segments.en: Hey guys, what do you think of my automobile?
segments.cn: 嘿，伙计们，你们觉得我的车怎么样？

segments.en: Isn't it bad to the bone?
segments.cn: 这车不是酷到骨子里吗？

segments.en: The ladies are going to be lining up to get with you when they see you driving around in that car.
segments.cn: 当女士们看到你开着这辆车时，会排队想和你在一起。

segments.en: When I do the nasty with the prom queen, we'll see who has the last laugh.
segments.cn: 当我和舞会女王亲热时，我们就看看谁笑到最后。

segments.en: Alright, so typical high school students of the decade, right?
segments.cn: 好吧，这就是那个年代典型的高中生，对吧？

segments.en: And well, of course, you always have the situation with the cool kids and maybe the kids that are not so cool and well, they're making fun of him, right?
segments.cn: 当然，你总是会看到酷孩子和不那么酷的孩子，他们在嘲笑他，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah, but they use some really cool words.
segments.cn: 是的，但他们使用了一些非常酷的词。

segments.en: So let's look at them now in language takeaway.
segments.cn: 现在让我们在语言收获中看看它们。

segments.en: Alright, so the first word that we saw in language takeaway and was really interesting, this word but ugly.
segments.cn: 好吧，我们在语言收获中看到的第一个词非常有趣，这个词but ugly。
所以当某样东西but ugly时，它真的很丑，对吧？

segments.en: So when something is but ugly, it's really ugly, right?

segments.cn: 而且but是指... 从你的... 底部。

segments.en: And what it would... butt is like... from your... your bottom.

segments.cn: 所以他说车很丑，另一个人回答说，嘿，别傻了。

segments.en: So he said the car was but ugly and the other guy answered by saying, hey, don't be an airhead.

segments.cn: 所以airhead是指脑袋里有空气的人。

segments.en: So an airhead is someone with air in their head.
So he said don't be an airhead.

segments.cn: 好吧，现在第三个词，他形容他的车是wicked。

segments.en: Okay, so this is a very 80s way of saying it's gonna be cool.
segments.cn: 好吧，这是一种非常80年代的说法，意思是它会很酷。

segments.en: And now when they saw another car pulling up, a new car, he described it as a fresh ride.
segments.cn: 现在当他们看到另一辆新车驶来时，他形容它为fresh ride。

segments.en: Now we understand that ride is a car, right?
segments.cn: 现在我们明白“ride”是指车，对吧？

segments.en: It's another way of saying cool.
segments.cn: 这就是另一种说“酷”的方式。

segments.en: Now finally at the end of our dialogue, they said you're a real scumbag, Charlie.
segments.cn: 现在在我们对话的最后，他们说你真是个混蛋，查理。

segments.en: So this word scumbag is interesting.
segments.cn: 所以这个词“混蛋”很有趣。

segments.en: Yeah, it's interesting and it's still used today, I would say.
segments.cn: 是的，这很有趣，今天仍然在用。

segments.en: So when someone is a scumbag, they're just really not a nice person.
segments.cn: 所以当某人是混蛋时，他们真的不是个好人。

segments.en: Yeah, they're not nice or they're not, maybe to a certain point, honest.
segments.cn: 是的，他们不友好，或者在某种程度上不诚实。

segments.en: Okay, but it's not a very harsh word, right?
segments.cn: 好吧，但这不是个很严厉的词，对吧？

segments.en: It's not harsh to call somebody a scumbag?
Well, it's not like a swear word, but it's certainly not a nice thing to say to someone.
segments.cn: 嗯，这不是脏话，但对某人说这绝对不是好事。

segments.en: Alright, so let's listen to all these adjectives that we've just looked at right now, again in our dialogue, and then we'll come Jim, what's up, man?
segments.cn: 好吧，让我们再听一遍我们刚刚看到的所有形容词，在我们的对话中，然后我们来听听吉姆，怎么样，伙计？

segments.en: I just need to fix it up a bit.
segments.cn: 我只需要稍微修理一下。

segments.en: In a couple of months, this baby's gonna be wicked.
segments.cn: 几个月后，这辆车会很酷。

segments.en: Too bad the driver is a major dweeb.
Anyone can have a car like that if their daddy's loaded like his.
segments.cn: 如果他们的爸爸像他一样有钱，任何人都可以有这样的车。

segments.en: Hey guys, what do you think of my automobile?
segments.cn: 嘿，伙计们，你们觉得我的车怎么样？

segments.en: Isn't it bad to the bone?
Word, the ladies are gonna be lining up to get with you when they see you driving around in that car.
segments.cn: 说得好，女士们看到你开着那辆车时，会排队想和你在一起。

segments.en: You are a real scumbag, Charlie.
When I do the nasty with the prom queen, we'll see who has the last laugh.
segments.cn: 当我和舞会女王亲热时，我们会看看谁笑到最后。

segments.en: Okay, well, you know what Marco?
I love the language of the 80s.
I love the music of the 80s.
And I'm really loving these phrases from the 80s.
segments.cn: 我真的很喜欢这些80年代的短语。

segments.en: So why don't we look at them now in Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 那我们现在在流利构建器中看看它们吧。

segments.en: Alright, so on Fluency Builder today, let's take a look at these phrases that you were talking about.
segments.cn: 好吧，今天在流利构建器上，让我们看看你们刚才提到的这些短语。

segments.en: And the first one is very interesting.
So these two guys that were making fun of this other person that was in this nice car, and he called him a major dweeb.
segments.cn: 这两个家伙在嘲笑那个开着好车的人，他叫他个大傻瓜。

segments.en: Now let's break this into two parts first.
segments.cn: 现在我们先把这个分成两部分。

segments.en: Well, let's see what dweeb means.
segments.cn: 好吧，让我们看看“dweeb”是什么意思。

segments.en: Well, a dweeb is a very uncool person.
Okay, so kind of similar to a nerd.
Yeah, a small kind of guy with no power.
segments.cn: 是的，一个小家伙，没有权力。

segments.en: Now this word major just means big, really serious.
segments.cn: 这个词“major”只是意味着大，非常严重。

segments.en: So it's a way of emphasizing.
segments.cn: 所以这是强调的一种方式。

segments.en: And you can say anything, you can have a major anything like, I've got a major headache.
segments.cn: 你可以说任何事情，你可以有一个“major”什么，比如，我有个大头痛。

segments.en: Or I can say I have a major problem this week.
segments.cn: 或者我可以说我这周有个大问题。

segments.en: Okay, so major, a very big problem.
segments.cn: 好吧，所以“major”，一个非常大的问题。

segments.en: Now they're talking about this really cool car.
segments.cn: 现在他们在谈论这辆非常酷的车。

segments.en: And the guy who was a bit of a dweeb, he said, isn't it bad to the bone?
segments.cn: 而那个有点傻的家伙说，这不是酷到骨子里吗？

segments.en: All right, now, this is also part of a famous song bad to the bone.
segments.cn: 好吧，这也是一首著名歌曲“bad to the bone”的一部分。

segments.en: Well, when something is bad to the bone, it's super cool.
segments.cn: 嗯，当某事酷到骨子里时，它超级酷。

segments.en: It's like, it's so dangerous that it's cool.
segments.cn: 就像，它是如此危险以至于它很酷。

segments.en: Now, this is not used anymore.
No, no, no, don't walk out of your house and use this this phrase tomorrow.
segments.cn: 不，不，不，明天别走出家门用这个短语。

segments.en: All right, so but it's interesting to know because there is a famous song that has this phrase in it.
segments.cn: 好吧，但知道这很有趣，因为有一首著名的歌曲包含这个短语。

segments.en: All right, so the car was so cool.
It was bad to the bone that all of the ladies would be wanting to get with the driver.
segments.cn: 它酷到骨子里，以至于所有女士们都想和司机在一起。

segments.en: All right, so somebody wants to get with you.
segments.cn: 好吧，有人想和你在一起。

segments.en: He just wants to get with you.
So if you want to get with someone you have you want to have sex with them.
segments.cn: 所以如果你想和某人在一起，你想和他们发生性关系。

segments.en: So if you want to get with someone, basically, it means that you want to have sex with them.
segments.cn: 所以如果你想和某人在一起，基本上意味着你想和他们发生性关系。

segments.en: But there's another phrase that was used in the dialogue that means pretty much the same thing.
segments.cn: 但对话中还有另一个短语，意思几乎相同。

segments.en: Now this was a very popular way of saying it in the 80s.
segments.cn: 这在80年代是一种非常流行的说法。

segments.en: It means to have sex as well.
segments.cn: 这也意味着发生性关系。

segments.en: But but this one is a little bit rude, isn't it?
segments.cn: 但这个有点粗鲁，不是吗？

segments.en: Yeah, I think it's a little bit more direct.
segments.cn: 是的，我觉得这有点直接。

segments.en: If you and your friends are talking and you say, hey, I think that girl wants to get with you.
segments.cn: 如果你和朋友在聊天，你说，嘿，我觉得那个女孩想和你在一起。

segments.en: It's a little bit more casual and less obvious.
segments.cn: 这有点随意，不那么明显。

segments.en: Do the nasty is a little bit more... a little more rude.
segments.cn: 做那种事有点... 有点粗鲁。

segments.en: Yeah, a little bit more direct.
And now the last phrase that we're going to look at today was made famous by the cartoons The Simpsons.
segments.cn: 现在我们要看的最后一个短语是由《辛普森一家》这部卡通片使其出名的。

segments.en: And it's don't have a cow.
So to not have a cow.
Don't have a cow means... To get really angry, to freak out, to get upset.
segments.cn: 不要发怒的意思是... 非常生气，崩溃，感到不安。

segments.en: So now we know that you say don't have a cow.
segments.cn: 所以现在我们知道你说不要发怒。

segments.en: But can I say it and use it in the positive?
segments.cn: 但我可以在积极的情况下使用它吗？

segments.en: Can I say, hey, my boss totally had a cow today in the office?
segments.cn: 我可以说，嘿，我的老板今天在办公室完全发怒了吗？

segments.en: So it freaked out, got angry, made a big deal of something.
segments.cn: 所以他崩溃了，生气了，夸大了一些事情。

segments.en: So Frank's gonna have a cow when he finds out I smashed his car.
segments.cn: 所以当弗兰克发现我撞了他的车时，他会发怒。

segments.en: Of course, Frank is gonna have a cow.
How can you smash his car?
But now it's time for us to listen to this dialogue for the last time.
segments.cn: 但现在是我们最后一次听这个对话的时候了。

segments.en: And then we'll come back and talk a little bit more about this decade of the 1980s.
segments.cn: 然后我们会回来再谈谈1980年代这个十年。

segments.en: I just need to fix it up a bit.
segments.cn: 我只需要稍微修理一下。

segments.en: In a couple of months, this baby is gonna be wicked.
segments.cn: 几个月后，这辆车会很酷。

segments.en: Too bad the driver's a major dweeb.
Anyone can have a car like that if their daddy's loaded like his.
segments.cn: 如果他们的爸爸像他那样有钱，任何人都可以有这样的车。

segments.en: Hey, guys, what do you think of my automobile?
segments.cn: 嘿，伙计们，你们觉得我的汽车怎么样？

segments.en: Isn't it bad to the bone?
The ladies are going to be lining up to get with you when they see you driving around in that car.
segments.cn: 当女士们看到你开着那辆车时，她们会排队想和你在一起。

segments.en: When I do the nasty with the prom queen, we'll see who has the last laugh.
segments.cn: 当我和舞会女王发生关系时，我们就看看谁笑到最后。

segments.en: Okay, so Marco, when I was listening to the dialogue this time, I heard a really cool word.
segments.cn: 好吧，马尔科，这次我听对话时，听到了一个很酷的词。

segments.en: Now, this was a very popular thing during the 80s when you would say to somebody, psych.
segments.cn: 这在80年代非常流行，当你对某人说开玩笑。

segments.en: So this is like saying, just kidding.
segments.cn: 所以这就像是在说，开玩笑。

segments.en: So you would say, Oh, Eric, I really like your hat.
segments.cn: 所以你会说，哦，埃里克，我真的很喜欢你的帽子。

segments.en: So that's how you would use it.
segments.cn: 所以这就是你会使用它的方式。

segments.en: You would give somebody a compliment or you would lie to somebody and then tell them psych and then like tell them the truth like, Oh, that hat is terrible or I was just kidding.
segments.cn: 你会给某人一个赞美，或者对某人撒谎，然后告诉他们开玩笑，然后告诉他们真相，比如，哦，那顶帽子真糟糕，或者我只是在开玩笑。

segments.en: So psych, what a great phrase.
segments.cn: 所以开玩笑，真是个好短语。

segments.en: And when I was in school, we would use it as well.
segments.cn: 当我在学校时，我们也会使用它。

segments.en: We would psych each other out.
So do we still use this phrase today?
segments.cn: 那么我们今天还会使用这个短语吗？

segments.en: I don't think we use it today.
segments.cn: 我觉得我们今天不再使用它了。

segments.en: I don't think it's cool anymore.
Well, if you'd use it, it's kind of like you're joking, right?
segments.cn: 好吧，如果你使用它，就像你在开玩笑，对吧？

segments.en: And I think it would make people laugh like, you know, it's pretty funny.
segments.cn: 我觉得这会让人们笑，知道吗，这很有趣。

segments.en: You're joking about how you're a little bit old fashioned.
segments.cn: 你在开玩笑，说明你有点过时。

segments.en: I'm very sure you would surprise a lot of your native English speaking friends if you use this phrase.
segments.cn: 我很确定如果你使用这个短语，会让很多说英语的朋友感到惊讶。

segments.en: A good one to try out.
segments.cn: 这是一个值得尝试的好短语。

segments.en: Now, if you have any questions about this phrase or any other of the language, come to our website at EnglishPod.com.
segments.cn: 现在，如果你对这个短语或其他语言有任何问题，请访问我们的网站EnglishPod.com。

segments.en: We're there to answer all your questions and also let us know any other lessons or topics that you would like to learn about in the future.
segments.cn: 我们会回答你所有的问题，也请告诉我们你未来想学习的其他课程或主题。

segments.en: Well, thanks for listening to this lesson, you guys.
segments.cn: 好吧，感谢你们收听这节课。
